source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_022_chunk4
evidence_span: hydrogen generated by the corrosion process accelerated the corrosion rate of the pickled specimens, if the hydrogen content was sufficiently high, 150- to 600-ppm H₂
conditions: 500°C static autoclave, hydrogen partial pressure 0.025 to 0.1 MPa
corrosion_data: hydrogen accelerates corrosion rate at 150-600 ppm H₂

extra_properties.effect: corrosion acceleration increases with hydrogen pressure, most pronounced for poor in-pile corrosion claddings

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_022_chunk6
evidence_span: prefilmed surface: 608 to $2 5 0 0 ~ \mathrm { m g } / \mathrm { d m } ^ { 2 }$ and $\bullet$ coarse ground surface: 3900 to $6 3 0 0 ~ \mathrm { m g } / \mathrm { d m } ^ { 2 }$

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_022_chunk6
evidence_span: Rod average thickness at 30.000 EFPH versus oxide weight gain of prefilmed specimens obtained in a ${ 5 2 0 ^ { \circ } C }$ autoclave test
corrosion_data: correlation between rod average oxide thickness and oxide weight gain

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_022_chunk6
evidence_span: A $5 0 0 \mathrm { { } ^ { \circ } C }$ , 10.3-MPa, 24-h static or refreshed autoclave test is not capable of fully predicting the Zircaloy-2 BWR corrosion properties
corrosion_data: not capable of fully predicting BWR corrosion properties

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_022_chunk6
evidence_span: increasing amount of hydrogen in the gas phase increases the corrosion rate of pickled specimens. However, prefilmed specimens appear to be unaffected by the hydrogen content
corrosion_data: hydrogen increases corrosion rate for pickled specimens, no effect on prefilmed

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_022_chunk6
evidence_span: increasing oxygen content in the steam decreases the corrosion rate of pickled specimens

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_022_chunk6
evidence_span: Corrosion rates are increased if pickled specimens are ground to a rougher surface. If pickled specimens are prefilmed, the corrosion rates are decreased
corrosion_data: ground surface increases corrosion, prefilming decreases corrosion

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_022_chunk6
evidence_span: a special $5 5 0 0 – \mathbf { k } \mathbf { g }$ ingot was triple melted. The composition was intentionally varied within a controlled portion of the ASTM range along the ingot length

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_022_chunk6
evidence_span: Strip specimens $\mathbf { 0 . 6 7 \ m \bar { m } }$ thick) were fabricated using three process schedules spanning the annealing parameter $( \Sigma A , = \Sigma t , \exp \mathrm { ~ - ~ } Q / R T , )$ range

extra_properties.annealing_parameter_range: three schedules spanning production practice range

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_022_chunk6
evidence_span: Corrosion weight gains were obtained from a ${ 5 0 0 } ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C }$ static autoclave test. A statistically significant reduction in ${ 5 0 0 ^ { \circ } C }$ weight gain was found as (1) the percentage nickel and iron increased; (2) the percentage of tin decreased; and (3) the accumulated annealing parameter decreased
corrosion_data: weight gain reduction with: increased Ni/Fe, decreased Sn, decreased annealing parameter

extra_properties.composition_effects: Ni/Fe increase reduces corrosion, Sn decrease reduces corrosion

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_022_chunk7
evidence_span: A "controlled composition" is defined where nickel and iron are adjusted towards the upper ASTM composition limits and tin is adjusted towards the lower limit. The $5 0 0 ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C }$ weight gain of controlled composition Zircaloy-2 is basically insensitive to accumulated annealing parameter over the range of $6 . 2 \times 1 0 ^ { - 2 1 } \mathrm { { h } }$ to $1 . 1 \times 1 0 ^ { - 1 7 } \mathsf { h }$
composition_raw: controlled composition (Ni/Fe towards upper ASTM limits, Sn towards lower limit)
corrosion_data: insensitive to annealing parameter (6.2×10⁻²¹ to 1.1×10⁻¹⁷ h)

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_022_chunk7
evidence_span: The effect of beta quench rate on $5 0 0 \%$ weight gains was also determined for Zircaloy-2 controlled composition material. Weight gains varied less than $5 ~ \mathrm { m g } / \mathrm { d } \mathrm { m } ^ { 2 }$ over a range of surface cooling rates from 18 to $3 6 \% r / s$ .
composition_raw: controlled composition (Ni/Fe towards upper ASTM limits, Sn towards lower limit)

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_022_chunk7
evidence_span: Analysis of the effect of beta quench rates on the uniform and nodular corrosion of Zircaloy4 was performed. Uniform corrosion post-transition rates are not significantly affected by beta quench rate for 360, 400, and $4 2 0 \textdegree C$ autoclave tests.
corrosion_data: not significantly affected by beta quench rate

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_022_chunk7
evidence_span: During $4 5 0 ^ { \circ } C$ testing, unrecrystallized microstructures of Zircaloy-4 promoted retention of tight, adherent oxide layers for much longer exposures than fully recrystallized microstructures.
corrosion_data: promoted retention of tight, adherent oxide layers

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_022_chunk7
evidence_span: $5 0 0 \%$ static autoclave weight gains are inversely proportional to the logarithm of the cooling rate for Zircaloy-4.
corrosion_data: inversely proportional to logarithm of cooling rate

extra_properties.correlation: weight gain inversely proportional to log(cooling rate)
